messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:17): aw, hsivonen didn't reply to mjs' idea
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:37): were you hoping he would?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:38): I guess his opinion on it is pretty relevant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:41): i asked him to :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:41): i'm waiting for his opinion before replying myself
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:52): introducing a level of conformance between "conforming" and "down-played errors" that shows a validator warning but is still conforming
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (00:52): I guess that makes sense
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (00:53): I don't see any downsides
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:54): personally i'm not a big fan of new conformance levels
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:54): we've already got three
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:55): and generally i don't see the point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:55): Transitional showed that people don't hesitate to use the low-level ones
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (00:56): what stuff is downplayed errors atm?  presentational guff?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:56): and XHTML has shown that other people try to be as strict as possible regardless of whether it's ok or not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:56): so it doesn't really have the desired effect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:57): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#conformance-checkers-0
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:00): I don't know what I'd do in this situation
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:00): four levels of conformance seems a little silly
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:01): the point is that peope don't like being told that they are non-conformant
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:01): yet they might like being told that they're wrong
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:01): and since the distinction doesn't really matter in practice, you might as well accomodate them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:02): i think i might be more happy to making the others downplayed errors into this "warning" class than introducing a new class altogether
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:02): I'm just worried about falling into the HTML4 Transitional trap
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:02): but anyway, i'd like hsivonen's input on the topic
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:02): since right now, he's the main one this affects
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yeah, I was thinking that might be an idea
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:03): probably make people happier about profile="" too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): yeah i'm really worried about doing another transitional
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (01:03): (though I'm not sure that's necessarily a good thing. :))
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): well that's the thing

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): profile="" and summary="" are very similar in this respect. They make people think they're doing something useful while really they are only wasting their time, even though in theory it could have been useful
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): s/it/they/

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think making downplayed errors into warnings (that must be reported but don't break conformance) would be a good change and one that hsivonen could probably go along with
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i'm worried about making teh HTML4 Transitional mistake.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, profile is worse than summary in that respect. The usefulness of summary is dependent upon the competence of the author writing it
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:18): what were the consequences of "the HTML4 transitional mistake"?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (01:18): right, whereas the usefulness of profile is zero, regardless of the competence of the author using it. :)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah, arguably profile is worse, but then arguably summary is worse because when the author inevitably screws up, he hurts more users.
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:18): doesn't really know the history
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64: people never transitioned.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:19): whereas the usefulness of profile is dependent upon a majority of authors getting it right, not just the one who chooses to use it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64: basically, people went to the lowest common denominator
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:19): how is that relevant to this case? you're afraid people won't transition to the better markup unless it's a conformance error?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64: i guess we might avoid that if hsivonen makes these downplayed errors into warnings that are always present, and doesn't just say "yup you're valid"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): 150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64: yeah, more or less
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:20): I know. summary isn't particularly conducive to people getting it right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:20): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: arguably summary="" is useless because too many people have gotten it wrong already. :-)
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:20): seems like we're mostly debating semantics :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): worse than semantics
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): psychology :-/
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:21): maybe the validator can call them "conformant errors"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): hah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: so you'd be ok with the proposal i described, if we just made the downplayed errors into frowned-upon-but-ok? i.e. changed from "not serious errors" to "discouraged non-errors"?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:22): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, that depends on the ability of ATs being able to reliably filter out useless values, which we've been told they do, but been given no details about how
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah, that information would definitely help
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:22): nor how reliable it is
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): we really should do usability testing of this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:22): it's hard to do usability testing for AT users, though

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:22): Maybe the validator should do like what the Yahoo and Google page speed tools do, giving each message a red/yellow/green severity and showing them in decreasing order of severity, so you can see which issues are the most worth fixing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): because you have to go to their setups, you can't just have them come in
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:23): if they have laptops, then you could have them come in with them
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:23): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think that would be a good improvement beyond even the summary="" issue
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): from what i've seen of usability studies of AT users here at google, they don't. at least not the ones we found for our studies.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: and yes, I would be in favor of that proposal

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: ok. i'll see what hsivonen thinks, and will see if i can find a way to phrase it that satisfies both the desire to keep these things as second-class citizens, and the desire to allow them to some extent.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:25): how is that different from the downplayed errors we already have in the spec?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:26): a document containing a downplayed error is nonconforming
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:27): so maybe we should have conformance levels, conceptually like the WCAG accessibility levels?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:27): Sounds like it's going to be horrendously confusing to someone who just wants to be told whether their page is okay or not
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:27): but then, that's getting closer to the idea of Strict/Transitional conformance
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: "good", "ok, with some problems" and "bad" doesn't seem that confusing
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (01:31): but even with those three buckets there are going to be arguments as to what goes where
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:33): yeah, my idea sucks. Don't listen to me.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:33): "strict", "transitional", "invalid"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:34): I think "good with no warnings", "good with warnings" and "bad, there are some errors" are sensible states
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:34): that is what programmers get from compilers and such
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:37): that seems reasonable. Though it still sucks having to settle for compromises like this just to stop the arguments.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:37): my personal point of view is that it's the right thing to do, not just a compromise
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:38): because sometimes, there are things that are often but not universally bad, and the right treatment is a mandatory but nonfatal diagnostic
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:38): some people will only care about error-free and take the warnings on a case-by-case basis, some will want their pages warning-free too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:39): I disagree, but fair enough
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:39): That's fair enough, I think the problem are the people who just see "Okay" and ignore the "but"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:39): The validator could let you specify -Werror and Wno-foo
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): yes, the validator should be able to toggle warning classes and also optionally treat warnings as fatal
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:39): (for all values of foo)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): I personally would want to use it in that mode, I think
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:40): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, are you suggesting this be applied to all attributes that are currently considered downplayed errors, or just to summary?

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e proposed converting the whole "downplayed error" class into something warning-like (i.e. does not break conformance)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): I think having "error" and "warning" instead of "error" and "downplayed error" as the two classes of diagnostics makes sense
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): yeah, i could reluctantly be convinced of that, i think
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): I haven't reviewed every current use of downplayed error, so I don't have an opinion on which should become nonfatal and which should be fatal
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:44): it would probably merit case-by-case review, since for some it may make sense to just convert them back to errors

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): (i was reading a scifi story recently where people could run simulations of their mental processes on a computer, and at one point one of the characters is in a debate
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:44): and he just ran 15,000 simulations of how the argument might play out with his simulated mental processes in "vm"s
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:45): in 95% of cases he was convinced. so he just decided to assume he'd be convinced, and skip the 15 minutes discussion that would otherwise ensue.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:45): i find this a fascinating concept.)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:46): I suppose that is meta-rational
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:46): (though sometimes it's important to know why you have been convinced)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (01:47): begins simulating tomorrow's public-html discussions
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:47): Isn't that kind of missing the part of the debate that involves exchanging information with the other participant and becoming better informed?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:47): the simulation included a simulation of the other participant
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:48): hmm, did annevk ever put the client rect and caret from point stuff in the CSSOM Editor's Draft?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:48): or is it somewhere else?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:49): A simulation based on the first person's mental representation of the second person? (in which case the first person still wouldn't be able to learn anything new)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:49): i don't recall the specifics

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:51): "authors should be aware that additional media resources might be necessary" - but they are allowed to be unaware if they have valid reasons to be, though presumably they will have to somehow wipe their minds after carefully weighing the full implications and deciding to become unaware of it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:51): is that in html5?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:52): notes that he is aware he is making a trivial point and ignoring all the important issues presented in the email
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: No, in sayrer's recent post to public-html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:53): ah ok

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:58): supposes a more constructive way to phrase the feedback would be to say that the proposed text uses the word "should" with no intended normative meaning, which is inconsistent with how that word is used throughout the rest of HTML 5
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:58): but that's a boring way to say it
